content:
• Thursday, February 5, 2015
  • BOX

    Box falls to new post-IPO lows

    • Following today's 2.6% drop in regular trading, BOX is down 28% from its first-day close of $23.23, and up only 19% from its $14 IPO price. A healthy 2.5M shares were traded today.
    • Philippe Laffont's Coatue Management is a believer in the enterprise cloud storage/file-syncing firm: The hedge fund recently disclosed a 10% stake.
    • Prior Box coverage
     
     
     
     
    | 8:02 PM | 9 Comments
  • MXWL

    Maxwell -13.3% due to soft Q1/2015 guidance

    • Though it beat Q4 estimates, Maxwell (NASDAQ:MXWL) is guiding for 2015 revenue of $160M-$180M, below a $207.8M consensus and down from a 2014 level of $186.6M. Revenue is expected to fall as much as 35% Q/Q in Q1 - a 35% drop would imply revenue of $34.4M, far below a $47.9M consensus.
    • CEO Franz Fink blames "the impact of the Chinese New Year holiday shutdown, historic seasonality, increasing price pressure in the Chinese bus market and the uncertainty of the impact of a higher Swiss franc exchange rate" for the Q1 outlook. Q/Q growth is expected in subsequent quarters.
    • Ultrapcacitor sales rose 56% Y/Y in Q4 to $40.9M, while high-voltage capacitor and microelectronics sales fell 6% to $12M. Fink declares Maxwell is "very encouraged with the progress we are making in diversifying the ultracapacitor revenue base with our Engine Start Module for trucks, further penetration of the automotive market and initial installations in the wayside rail and grid firming markets."
    • Gross margin fell to 35% from 37% a year ago, and operating expenses rose to $17.3M (33% of revenue) from $15.9M (41% of revenue). Maxwell ended Q4 with $24.7M in cash, down from $30.8M at the end of Q3.
    • Shares are down to $7.15 AH; the 52-week low is $7.06. Q4 results, PR.
     
     
     
     
    | 7:32 PM | 2 Comments
  • ATVI

    Activision -8.1% on sales miss, guidance; $750M buyback launched

    • Activision (NASDAQ:ATVI) expects Q1 revenue of $640M and EPS of $0.05, well below a consensus of $777.7M and $0.18. Full-year guidance (harder to project for a game developer) is for revenue of $4.4B and EPS of $1.15, below a consensus of $4.71B and $1.15.
    • The board has authorized a new $750M buyback program. It lasts through Feb. 2017, and is good for repurchasing 5% of shares at current levels. Activision also plans to pay off a $250M term loan; the company had $4.3B in debt at the end of Q4, and $4.8B in cash.
    • Thanks to the launch of the Warlords of Draenor expansion pack, the World of Warcraft subscriber base was above 10M at the end of 2014, up from 7.4M at the end of Q3.
    • The expansion pack drove a 98% Y/Y increase in online revenue to $398M. However, console revenue fell 15% to $1.22B, thanks to a 48% drop in prior-gen console revenue to $599M; next-gen console revenue more than doubled to $630M. PC game revenue rose 14% to $127M; mobile/other revenue fell 18% to $269M; and distribution revenue rose 6% to $190M.
    • 31% and 46% of Q4 and full-year revenue respectively came from digital channels, up from 16% and 36% a year earlier. Q4 GAAP R&D spend fell 7% to $184M, and sales/marketing 3% to $247M.
    • Shares have fallen to $20.05 AH.
    • Q4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 6:34 PM | 9 Comments
  • NTLS

    NTELOS lower in late trade after extending Dir's leadership

    • Telecom NTELOS Holdings (NASDAQ:NTLS) has filed an 8-K saying that it has entered a new contract with its president and COO Rodney Dir to serve aa CEO (as an independent contractor) for the rest of 2015.
    • Dir had been given a contract last summer to act as president while the comopany searched for a permanent CEO/president. He has been a director at NTELOS since October 2011.
    • Details: Dir will report directly to the board and be compensated with $425K base pay, a bonus opportunity of $300K, 50,000 shares of restricted stock and a housing allowance.
    • The company also appointed Michael Gottdenker to its board.
    • After gaining 6.5% today, shares turned lower after hours, down 6.1%.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:30 PM
  • GSB

    GlobalSCAPE jumps 15.5% after earnings

    • GlobalSCAPE (NYSEMKT:GSB): Q4 EPS of $0.06
    • Revenue of $7.9M (+27.4% Y/Y)
    • Shares +15.5% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:05 PM
  • GPRO

    GoPro -14.8% after providing guidance; Ambarella -4%

    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) has guided on its Q4 CC for Q1 revenue of $330M-$340M and EPS of $0.15-$0.17. The former is above a $324.7M consensus, but the latter is below a $0.17 consensus at the midpoint.
    • A culprit for the EPS guidance: GoPro expects its gross margin to drop to 44% from Q4's 48%.
    • GoPro has fallen to $46.31 AH. Video processor supplier Ambarella (NASDAQ:AMBA) is down to $56.83.
    • Prior GoPro coverage
     
     
     
     
    | 6:02 PM | 40 Comments
  • YELP

    Yelp traffic: Growth, but slowing down considerably

    • Slowing traffic numbers at Yelp (NYSE:YELP) may be holding down the stock (now down 12.1%) after its Q4 earnings beat.
    • Average monthly unique visitors of about 135M was up 13% Y/Y -- but that growth was off from 39% the year before, and from 19% growth in Q3. Sequentially, monthly unique visitors slipped from Q3's 139M.
    • Average monthly mobile unique visitors of 72M was up 37% Y/Y; that growth is down sequentially from Q3's 46% and Q2's 51%.
    • Active local business accounts of 93,700 were up about 39% Y/Y. Local advertising accounts of 84,000 was up 48% from the prior year.
    • The company said it grew into 25 countries in 2014, in addition to 56 international markets it served at the end of 2013.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:56 PM | 2 Comments
  • MSFT

    LinkedIn soars to $256 on Q4 beat, ad growth pickup

    • LinkedIn (LNKD) is guiding for Q1 revenue of $618M-$622M (below a $645.7M consensus) and full-year revenue of $2.93B-$2.95B (in-line with a $2.94B consensus). However, the company has a long history of sandbagging sales guidance. Q1 EPS guidance of $0.53 is below a $0.55 consensus, but full-year EPS guidance of $2.95 is above a $2.73 consensus.
    • Q4 Talent Solutions revenue (jobs, 57% of total revenue) +41% Y/Y to $369M; Marketing Solutions (ads, 24% of revenue) +56% to $153M; Premium Subscriptions (19% of revenue) +38% to $121M. Marketing Solutions growth accelerated sharply from Q3's 45%. International was once more 40% of total revenue.
    • The deferred revenue balance rose 33% Y/Y to $522.3M. GAAP costs/expenses rose 44% to $629.3M; sales/marketing spend totaled $224.3M, and R&D $150.3M.
    • LNKD +7.8% AH to $256.60. The all-time high for regular trading (set in 2013) is $257.56.
    • Q4 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:48 PM | 7 Comments
  • NUAN

    Nuance -2.5% due to light guidance, new bookings drop

    • Though it beat FQ1 estimates, Nuance (NASDAQ:NUAN) has guided in its prepared remarks (.pdf) for FQ2 revenue of $459M-$475M and EPS of $0.22-$0.26, below a consensus of $499.5M and $0.27. FY15 (ends Sep. '15) guidance is for revenue of $1.907B-$1.957B and EPS of $1.08-$1.18; the latter is in-line with a $1.13 consensus, but the former is below a $2.05B consensus.
    • Net new bookings (excludes renewal bookings) fell 5.5% Y/Y in FQ1 to $303.8M. Nuance calls the 15 net new bookings it recorded "disappointing,"Â  and (thanks in part to forex) is lowering its FY15 net new bookings growth guidance to 4%-5% from 6%-8%.
    • Thanks to the shift towards cloud/subscription revenue streams, the deferred revenue balance rose 28.2% to $484.3M. On-demand solutions made up 36% of revenue.
    • Healthcare organic revenue growth was flat, mobile/consumer was -5%, enterprise -4%, and imaging -9%. Total organic growth was -3%. GAAP operating expenses rose by less than $300K Y/Y to $278.2M.
    • Regarding mobile/consumer, Nuance notes mobile cloud transactions rose 66% Y/Y to 3.98B. But it also cautions it has "experienced pressure in the mobile phone industry as market share shifts among leading vendors and emerging companies, largely from China."
    • FQ1 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM | 4 Comments

  • After Hour Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: PTLA +16.4%. GSB +15.6%. TWTR +11.4%. UBNT +10.8%. YRCW +8.3%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: P -21.0%. FWM -15.0%. MXWL -14.6%. NTGR -13.5%. CTRL -10.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:35 PM
  • EOX

    Emerald Oil launches $25M stock offering

    • Emerald Oil (NYSEMKT:EOX) -7.2% AH after announcing a public offering of $25M in common stock, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional $3.75M of stock.
    • EOX says it plans to use the proceeds for working capital and general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:20 PM | 15 Comments
  • P

    Pandora's Q4: Gains in listeners, listener hours, RPMs

    • Pandora's (NYSE:P) Q4 miss featured some promising operating metrics despite a revenue miss and light guidance.
    • Total listener hours at 5.2B (up 15%) for Q4, and 20.03B (up 20%) for the full year.
    • Active listeners at end of Q4: 81.5M, up 7% from prior year.
    • Advertising RPMs (revenue per thousand listener hours) gained: total of $48.19 (up from prior-year $40.95); comprising Computer RPM of $68.83 (up from $61.92) and Mobile/connected devices RPM of $44.37 (up from $36.20).
    • Total RPM: $51.54 (up from prior-year $44.14); comprising computer RPM of $68.06 (up from prior $61.28) and mobile/connected devices RPM of $48.27 (up from prior $39.99).
    • The metric gains aren't entirely unexpected as Q4 is generally a stronger one for Pandora. Shares now down 19.3%.
    • Previously: Pandora plunges 19.9% after Q4 revenue miss (Feb. 05 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 5:18 PM
  • UEPS

    Net 1 UEPS Technologies beats by $0.09, misses on revenue

    • Net 1 UEPS Technologies (NASDAQ:UEPS): FQ2 EPS of $0.57 beats by $0.09.
    • Revenue of $154.13M (+12.3% Y/Y) misses by $1.27M.
    • Shares +1.69% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:13 PM | 1 Comment
  • GPRO

    GoPro's COO leaving; shares now -2.1%

    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) discloses COO Nina Richardson is leaving, effective Feb. 27. Shares have turned negative in response, after initially rising on account of the company's Q4 beat.
    • The Q4 CC is underway (webcast). Richardson's departure could spell a bigger role for president/ex-Skype CEO Tony Bates, who was hired shortly before the IPO.
    • Q4 results, details
     
     
     
     
    | 5:10 PM | 31 Comments
  • UBNT

    Ubiquiti +10.6% on enterprise-driven FQ2 beat

    • Ubiquiti's (NASDAQ:UBNT) service provider revenue fell 11% Y/Y in FQ2 to $99.7M. However, its enterprise revenue (boosted by strong UniFi Wi-Fi hardware demand) rose 98% to $53.4M.
    • The company is guiding for FQ3 revenue of $146M-$158M and EPS of $0.45-$0.50, almost entirely below a consensus of $157.9M and $0.51. However, FQ3 expectations were already low due to forex and emerging markets concerns. And a lot of bad news has been priced in over the last few months.
    • North America revenue (lifted by enterprise) +66% to $54.1M; South America -21% to $22.2M; EMEA +2% to $60.1M; Asia-Pac -12% to $16.7M.
    • Gross margin rose to 45.1% from 44.1% a year ago. GAAP operating expenses rose 33% to $18.3M, with R&D spend making up $12.9M of the total. $15M was spent on buybacks.
    • Shares are up to $29.00 AH.
    • FQ2 results, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 5:04 PM | 3 Comments
  • LGF.A

    Lions Gate trading down late after disappointing revenues

    • Despite an injection from the latest release in its Hunger Games franchise, Lions Gate Entertainment (LGF) logged a revenue miss for fiscal Q3 and traded lower after hours, -4.9%.
    • EBITDA of $146.77M beat expectations of $145.17M, but revenues of $751.3M were off from the prior year's $839.9M and missed expectations of $778.7M.
    • The company pointed to The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 1, strong TV series licensing, lower marketing, lower taxes and increased earnings from equity investments as highlights. CEO Jon Feltheimer pointed to growing margins across the business.
    • Motion Picture segment revenue was $590.1M (-22%); in that, theatrical revenue was $286.4M with only two releases (Hunger Games and John Wick) vs. four the previous year. Home entertainment revenue was $183.1M, down from prior $200.7M, mainly due to smaller film slate.
    • TV revenue was $82.9M vs. prior $105.8M; only one film (Divergent) reached its pay TV window vs. five the prior year.
    • Television Production revenue of $161.2M vs. $82.3M the prior year; record 74 episodes and 58.5 hours of domestic TV series delivered.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:01 PM | 1 Comment
  • GPRO

    GoPro +3.8% after big Q4 beat (updated)

    • GoPro (NASDAQ:GPRO) is higher AH after coming off a halt placed prior to the release of its big Q4 numbers.
    • The action camera maker says it shipped 2.4M capture devices in seasonally huge Q4, and 5.2M over the whole of 2014. Videos published on its YouTube channel rose 71% in 2014, video views 81%, and minutes watched over 140%. Cumulative GoPro app downloads are at 13M.
    • Gross margin rose to 48% from 44.5% in Q3 and 42% a year ago. GAAP operating expenses rose 61% Y/Y to $130.1M; R&D totaled $46.1M and sales/marketing $61.2M.
    • CC at 5PM ET. Guidance should be provided.
    • Q4 results, PR
    • Update: Shares have plunged after GoPro provided light EPS guidance and announced COO Nina Richardson is leaving.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:45 PM | 14 Comments
  • VZ

    Verizon confirms sale of wireline assets for $10B to Frontier

    • Moving swiftly yet again, Verizon (NYSE:VZ) confirms its plan to sell wireline assets in California, Florida and Texas to Frontier Communications (NYSE:FTR) for $10B ($9.9B cash and some $600M in assumed debt). It would be Frontier's biggest-ever deal.
    • Frontier shares up heavily after hours, +9.7%.
    • Verizon will also buy back up to $5B in stock.
    • Combined with a just-announced sale of cell towers to American Tower, Verizon should see the near-$15B intake expected, a vital step as the company must pay the FCC $10B this month to cover its bids in the AWS-3 spectrum auction.
    • Previously: WSJ: Frontier close to $10B buy of Verizon's wireline assets (Feb. 04 2015)
    • Previously: Verizon reaches $5B sale of towers to American Tower (Feb. 05 2015)
    • Previously: FCC releases winners in record spectrum auction (Jan. 30 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 9 Comments
  • NMM

    Navios Maritime Partners to launch 4M-unit offering

    • Navios Maritime Partners (NYSE:NMM) -4.7% AH after announcing plans to offer 4M common units in a public offering, with an underwriters option to purchase an additional 600K units.
    • NMM says it expects to use the proceeds to fund its fleet expansion and/or for general partnership purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:32 PM | 6 Comments
  • YELP

    Yelp 4% lower in late trading after Q4 earnings beat

    • Yelp (NYSE:YELP) is off 4% after hours despite an earnings beat and largely in-line guidance.
    • Revenues came in ahead of expectations and at 56% growth. EBITDA of $25.1M (up almost 150%) vs. expected $24.6M.
    • The company's Q1 outlook of $114M-116M in revenues is in line with a $115M consensus, and expected adjusted EBITDA of $19M-21M is on the light side of an expected $21M.
    • Yelp's full-year 2015 outlook of revenue from $538M-$543M is in line with an expected $538.3M, but adjusted EBITDA outlook of $100M-103M is significantly below an expected $120.3M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:28 PM | 2 Comments
  • TWTR

    Twitter +6.6%; Q4 ad growth strong, MAUs at 288M

    • After initially selling off AH in the wake of its Q4 beat and mixed guidance (quite possibly conservative, given the company's history), Twitter (NYSE:TWTR) has now rallied above $43.
    • Twitter averaged 288M monthly active users (MAUs) in Q4, up 47M Y/Y but just 4M Q/Q. The company notes 4M MAUs were lost in Q4 due to changes in 3rd-party Twitter integrations. Mobile MAUs were 80% of total MAUs.
    • Timeline views totaled 182B vs. 181B in Q3 and 148B a year ago. Twitter has argued Timeline views are an imperfect proxy of traffic, given its efforts to embed more media content within Timelines.
    • Ad revenue rose 97% Y/Y to $432M, after coming in at 109% in Q3. Data licensing/other revenue rose 105% to $47M. Mobile was 88% of ad revenue (up from Q3's 85%), and international 34% of total revenue (even with Q3).
    • GAAP costs/expenses totaled $577.2M; the year-ago figure of $752.3M is inflated by post-IPO stock compensation expenses. Q4 adjusted EBITDA was $141M, well above guidance of $100M-$105M. Q1 adjusted EBITDA guidance is at $89M-$94M, and full-year guidance at $550M-$570M (compares with 2014 adjusted EBITDA of $300.9M).
    • Q4 results/guidance, PR
     
     
     
     
    | 4:27 PM | 19 Comments
  • BWLD

    Buffalo Wild Wings: Blazing start for Q1 comps

    • Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) reports same-store sales rose 6.5% at company-owned restaurants and gained 5.6% at franchised restaurant during Q4.
    • Elevated chicken wing costs were a factor during the quarter.
    • Average weekly sales +6.7% to $62.12K at company-owned restaurants.
    • Average weekly sales +4.5% to $63.95K at franchised-owned outlets.
    • Cost of sales ratio +80 bps to 30.6%.
    • Labor costs ratio +110 bps to 31.1%.
    • Store count: Company-owned restaurants +38 Q/Q to 491, franchised restaurants +3 to 591.
    • Guidance: Through five weeks, Q1 comps are up over 11%.
    • BWLD +1.0% AH to $182.09.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM | 4 Comments
  • ON

    ON Semiconductor beats by $0.01, beats on revenue

    • ON Semiconductor (ONNN): Q3 EPS of $0.17 beats by $0.01.
    • Revenue of $964.2M (+34.3% Y/Y) beats by $108.09M.
    • Shares +5.2%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM
  • MSFT

    LinkedIn beats by $0.08, beats on revenue

    • LinkedIn (LNKD): Q4 EPS of $0.61 beats by $0.08.
    • Revenue of $643M (+43.8% Y/Y) beats by $26.17M.
    • Shares +5.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 3 Comments
  • MCK

    McKesson beats by $0.28, beats on revenue

    • McKesson (NYSE:MCK): FQ3 EPS of $2.89 beats by $0.28.
    • Revenue of $47.01B (+36.9% Y/Y) beats by $2.2B.
    • Shares +2.38%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:17 PM
  • P

    Pandora plunges 19.9% after Q4 revenue miss

    • Pandora (NYSE:P) is off significantly after hours, -19.9%, after an earnings report that missed on revenue, and which featured light guidance.
    • Revenue of $268M inclued $220.1M in advertising revenue (up 36%) and $47.9M in subscription revenue (up 24%).
    • Adjusted EBITDA of $43.8M (up 68%) vs. an expected $45.5M.
    • The company stated an outlook for fiscal Q1 of revenues in the range of $220M-225M, vs. consensus expectations of $241.8M, and adjusted EBITDA of -$35M to -$30M vs. expectations of -$9.6M.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM | 4 Comments
  • TWTR

    Twitter beats estimates; Q1 guidance light, full-year guidance better

    • Twitter (NYSE:TWTR): Q4 EPS of $0.12 beats by $0.06.
    • Revenue of $479.1M (+97.4% Y/Y) beats by $25.96M.
    • Expects Q1 revenue of $440M-$450M vs. a $449.7M consensus.
    • Expects 2015 revenue of $2.3B-$2.35B vs. a $2.3B consensus.
    • Shares -5.6% AH.
    • Update (4:27PM): Twitter has reversed course. Shares are now up 6.6% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:08 PM | 14 Comments
  • UNP

    Union Pacific promotes Fritz to CEO

    • Union Pacific (UNP +1.9%) promoted COO Lance Fritz to become the railroad's new President and CEO, effective immediately, succeed Jack Koraleski, who will remain as Executive Chairman.
    • Fritz has been COO and VP of operations since joining the company in 2010, and had worked for Fiskars, Cooper Industries and GE before joining UNP.
    • Separately, UNP approves a 10% increase in the quarterly dividend and announces a $4.3B capital spending plan for this year, including $450M for railroad anticrash technology; the spending plan is ~5% more than the ~$4.1B in capital outlays reported for 2014.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:58 PM
  • KOPN

    Himax slumps after Kopin unveils new microdisplay process

    • Kopin (KOPN +3.2%) has unveiled NanoJet, a liquid crystal cell assembly process (optimized for microdisplays) declared to offer superior image quality and brightness, as well as to lower display costs by improving yields and reducing materials usage.
    • Kopin: "The NanoJet process releases tiny drops of liquid crystal material with greater precision (variation within a few nano grams) and provides for a purer, better controlled and very uniform layering of the liquid crystal material in the fabrication of displays ...Â  We are qualifying the NanoJet process and expect a tier-one customer to introduce in coming months a wearable product which includes a display manufactured using the Nanojet process."
    • Microdisplay rival Himax (HIMX -3.6%) has sold off following the announcement. Shares soared two weeks ago after Microsoft revealed HoloLens, a holographic/augmented reality headset for which little has been disclosed regarding its display technology. Himax stated in November it has "some exciting new tier-1 customers" for its LCoS microdisplay; its Q4 results are due in seven days.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:57 PM | 37 Comments
  • GM

    Sterne Agee sees plenty of upside on GM

    • Sterne Agee backs its Buy rating on General Motors (GM +1.1%) after digesting the automaker's Q4 report.
    • "Auto operations in North America continue to show improvement, operations in China set another record, the company is taking actions to minimize the impact from some of the weaker regions," read the bullish note from Sterne.
    • The investment firm's price target of $50 implies considerable upside for investors.
    • Previously: General Motors 4% higher on positive results (Feb. 4)
    • Previously: GM +3.2% after solid profit read and dividend boost (Feb. 4)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM
  • PFE

    Money flowing into small biosimilar firms after Hospira takeout

    • Pfizer's (PFE +3%) acquisition of biosimilar developer Hospira (HSP +35.2%) has speculators moving into several smaller players.
    • Thinly-traded Coherus BioSciences (CHRS +13.2%) is up on a 3x surge in volume albeit on turnover of only 600K. Its lead product is a biosimilar version of Amgen's Enbrel (etanercept).
    • Thinly-traded Epirus Biopharmaceuticals (EPRS +3.3%) is up also on 3x higher volume but, again, on light turnover of 276K shares. Its lead product is a biosimilar version of Janssen's Remicade (infliximab).
    • Previously: Coherus Bio stumbles in debut (Nov. 6, 2014)
    • Previously: Sandoz success powers Epirus Bio (Jan. 8)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:51 PM | 1 Comment
  • FOXA

    Despite earnings beat, Fox tumbles on analyst actions

    • An earnings beat hasn't kept Twenty-First Century Fox (NASDAQ:FOXA) from a significant drop today -- down 5.6% -- after a spate of dim views from analysts.
    • FBR Capital Markets downgraded shares to Market Perform from Outperform and lowered its price target to $36 from $43. Rosenblatt initiated coverage with a Sell rating (and $30 target).
    • Topeka Capital Markets maintained their Buy rating, but with a lower target: $41 instead of $43.
    • Rupert Murdoch noted "currency headwinds" in his remarks yesterday, and FBR agrees: an "excellent company" but one now facing currency and FX challenges, along with secular headwinds for TV networks.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM
  • TEVA

    Departure of prominent Teva board member stokes speculative buying

    • The resignation of prominent healthcare investor/entrepreneur Dr. Phillip Frost, M.D., from Teva Pharmaceutical Industries' (TEVA +1.8%) Board of Directors prompts aggressive buying from speculators who think a potential deal is afoot with Opko Health (OPK +4.6%). Teva is up on 50% higher volume while Opko's turnover is 3x average.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:23 PM | 10 Comments
  • PRU

    Prudential call: Dude, where's my excess capital?

    • Unsurprisingly, analysts peppered Prudential Financial (PRU -5.9%) management in this morning's earnings call over the "disappearance" of about $1.5B of excess capital - the insurer reported a $2B figure vs. expectations of $3.5B.
    • The short answer, writes the WSJ's Leslie Scism: Falling interest rates - the big drop in the 10-year yield last year caught the company somewhat off guard - and tough state regulatory funding requirements.
    • Excess capital is what's used to fund buybacks, and management is "very comfortable" with the current level ($1B is authorized in the 12 months through June 30).
    • Sterne Agee: "How do you lose $1.5B of excess capital in two months?”
    • Previously: Prudential still a buy at Morgan Stanley, but price target cut (Feb. 5)
    • Previously: Prudential lower by 3.6% after miss (Feb. 4)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:16 PM | 2 Comments
  • X

    U.S. Steel still a Buy but price target cut by $21 at Argus

    • U.S. Steel (X -3.4%) is maintained with a Buy rating at Argus, but the firm cuts its target price to $32 from $53 based on its lower 2015 earnings forecast and prospects for significantly weaker performance in the tubular segment.
    • Management noted following Q4 earnings that tubular sales and earnings would be hurt by the sharp decline in oil prices as E&P companies cut back on purchases of drill pipe, but Argus thinks the weaker outlook already is factored into the share price following the post-earnings selloff.
    • The firm says its revised $32 target implies a multiple of 13.6x its 2016 EPS estimate, still near the low end of the historical range.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:11 PM

  • NTELOS up 6.5% on light volume

    • NTELOS Holdings is trading up 6.4% but on quite light volume -- 148K shares vs. a daily average 598K. The stock has started cresting its 30-day moving average.
    • A small group of analysts rates a consensus Hold on the stock, with an average price target of $7.83. Shares currently trade at $4.60.
    • Previously: NTELOS sells towers, provides Q4 subscriber numbers (Jan. 20 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:10 PM
  • CDNS

    Cadence -5% due to light EPS guidance

    Callon Petroleum says proved reserves rises 121%, cuts capex by 25%-30%

    • Callon Petroleum (CPE +10.2%) says its estimated total proved reserves rose 121% Y/Y to 33M boe at year-end 2014, with 55% classified as proved developed producing.
    • CPE says it plans a 2015 capital budget of $150M-$165M, 25%-30% below the comparable 2014 budgeted amount of $215M.
    • However, CPE sees 2015 production of 8,000-8,400 boe/day (~80% oil), up 45% Y/Y from 5,700 boe/day in 2014.
    • Says initial production rates at its initial Lower Spraberry wells averaged 891 boe/day.

    Tata Motors slides after earnings

    • Tata Motors (TTM -3.2%) trades lower after reporting FQ3 earnings.
    • Deliveries for the Jaguar Land Rover brand fell 0.6% Y/Y during the quarter.
    • Though there's been some bounce in the Indian automobile market, profit from the region still disappointed.
    • Previously: Tata Motors reports Q3 earnings
